headline: UBS, Jefferies Reveal They Could Take Multimillion-Dollar Hits From Bankrupt Autoparts Supplier
summary: Both  Jefferies Financial  and  UBS  have revealed nine-figure fund exposures to First Brands, a beleaguered auto-parts supplier that filed for bankruptcy in late September.  Jefferies on Wednesday disclosed that a unit of one of its asset managers had invested roughly a quarter of its $3 billion trade finance portfolio in assets tied to First Brands Group.  The unit, Point Bonita Capital, had bought about $715 million of “receivables”—customer invoices.

The unit, Point Bonita Capital, had bought about $715 million of “receivables”—customer invoices.

headline: Jefferies Fund Has $715 Million in First Brands’ Trade Debt
summary: Jefferies’ own investment in that fund along with some First Brands loans it bought brings its total exposure to the now-bankrupt firm to $161 million, the bank disclosed on Wednesday.  The exposure is mostly through Point Bonita Capital, a division of Jefferies’ Leucadia Asset Management, which manages trade-finance assets on behalf of third-party institutional and other investors.

raw.headline: Jefferies Fund Has $715 Million in First Brands’ Trade Debt

The exposure is mostly through Point Bonita Capital, a division of Jefferies’ Leucadia Asset Management, which manages trade-finance assets on behalf of third-party institutional and other investors.

headline: Is Walmart's (WMT) Push Into AI and Supply Chain Tech Reshaping Its Investment Story?
summary: In recent weeks, Walmart has accelerated its investment in supply chain innovation, e-commerce logistics, and wellness offerings, including launching new AI and ambient IoT initiatives, opening a $300 million fulfillment center, and adding Ritual and Kate Farms products to stores and online channels nationwide. These moves highlight Walmart’s ongoing leadership in technology-driven retail efficiency, as well as its focus on expanding healthier and more sustainable product choices for its...
